intro.title: Designing Homes That Hold Stories
intro.subtitle: A quiet scroll through living rooms, kitchens, and corners we’ve shaped — with stills, soft clips, and client words.

blocks.alt: Neutral living room with soft sofa and warm light

blocks.heading: A calm spine that quietly connects rooms.
blocks.body: Living, dining, and study are arranged along one clear axis. Storage is absorbed into walls so the floor stays open for everyday movement and light.

blocks.heading: Quiet geometry, warm tactility.
blocks.body: Ribbed panels, soft upholstery, and timber details sit over a very simple plan, so the home can evolve without ever feeling busy.

blocks.alt: Soft living room with warm indirect light and artwork

blocks.heading: Storage‑first, then styling.
blocks.body: Tall units hide appliances and pantry so the working counters feel light. The kitchen reads as part of the living room, not a separate zone.

blocks.label: Living room clip
blocks.caption: A calm interior opening to a terrace, captured the way it feels when you first wake up.

blocks.quote: We finally have a living room that feels effortless — there’s a place for everything without the space feeling full.
blocks.name: Akshay Dhavle

blocks.label: Bedroom clip
blocks.caption: A soft bedroom with neutral bedding and curtains, shown in a quiet walkthrough.

blocks.alt: Minimal bedroom with soft textiles and warm light

blocks.heading: Layered light for slow evenings.
blocks.body: Ceiling, wall, and bedside lights sit on separate circuits so the room can move from practical to completely calm.

blocks.quote: The bedroom finally feels like a retreat. We use the reading corner more than expected because it is naturally lit and comfortable.
blocks.name: Vidya Rajagopal
